title: Food Lion Owner Searches for New CFO to Boost Sales, Cut Costs
text:
Dutch grocer Koninklijke Ahold Delhaize NV is looking for a new finance chief to boost sales and cut costs across 10 countries, including the U.S., its biggest market.

The owner of grocery chains Food Lion and Stop & Shop and grocery delivery service Peapod on Monday said Chief Financial Officer Jeff Carr won’t return as a member of Ahold Delhaize’s management board after his current term expires in April 2020.

Mr. Carr became CFO of Ahold NV in 2011 and continued to lead the company’s finances after its merger with Belgium’s Delhaize Group in 2016. Ahold Delhaize has commenced the search for a successor, the Zaandam, Netherlands-based company said.

The change in the finance seat comes as the grocer seeks to increase sales while expanding e-commerce channels. Frans Muller, who last year became Ahold Delhaize’s chief executive, has laid out a strategy focusing on top-line growth through online retail, a revamp of the company’s Stop & Shop stores in the U.S. and acquisitions.

“There is plenty to be done on all three [fronts], especially in the U.S.,” said Bruno Monteyne, head of investment bank Sanford C. Bernstein Ltd.’s European food retail unit. Ahold Delhaize generated around 60% of its second-quarter net sales of €16.31 billion ($18.04 billion) in the U.S.

Online sales accounted only for 2.3%, or €221 million, of sales in the U.S., highlighting the challenges ahead for the management team, said Robert Jan Vos, an analyst at ABN Amro NV.

“This is something they need to focus on because the market is transforming,” Mr. Vos said. “And they need to be part of the transformation.”

Online giant Amazon.com Inc. ’s 2017 purchase of Whole Foods has put pressure on other grocers to expand their digital presence.

Ahold Delhaize said it is searching for a candidate with strong international experience who can help the company pursue comparable sales growth and market-share gains while driving down costs. The company plans to save a cumulative €1.8 billion by 2021.

“The CFO at Ahold typically gets quite involved in overseeing the annual cost savings program,” Mr. Monteyne said. “That is critical to stay competitive in any mature food retail market,” he said.

The planned €1.8 billion in saved costs should provide the company with enough cash to support its brands and develop its online channels, which will help it withstand competition, said Sophie Coutaux, a senior director at ratings firm Fitch Ratings Inc.

Shareholders might ask a new CFO about potential acquisition plans, analysts said.

Ahold Delhaize does not have a reputation for being a very acquisitive company, but currently returns around €1 billion a year to shareholders, Mr. Vos said. “You could also spend this billion on acquiring companies,” he said.

Mr. Carr said last year that the company was “considering opportunities that are related to technology and e-commerce.” He added, “We will keep our eyes open for acquisitions and partnerships.”

In the U.S., the company’s Stop & Shop business is still recovering from a strike in the second quarter. The strike—which revolved around employee pay and benefits—cost the company $224 million in lost sales and around $100 million in underlying operating income, Ahold Delhaize said in its latest earnings release.

“A new CFO will have to make some tough decisions on how to deal with the unions in the U.S.,” said Clément Genelot, a research analyst at Bryan, Garnier & Co.
